In the present study we aimed to explore changes on QEEG cordance with rTMS treatment in treatment resistant depression. A total of 71 subjects completed the protocol. Choice of SSRI antidepressant drug treatment was decided by their own treating physician, who remained responsible for dosing and any changes in medication during the study. Patients had taken part in a 3 week, 20 sessions, trial of 25 Hz, left prefrontal cortex rTMS adjunctive to their medication regime. The subjects were examined in three groups: remission, responder, nonresponder groups. Response was defined as a 50% reduction of the HAMD score. Patients with HAMD scores of less than 8 were considered to be in remission. In pretreatment QEEG, the remission group had lower delta and theta cordance in the left prefrontal regions as compared to non-responders. The delta and theta cordance of responders were also lower than the theta cordance of nonresponse group in the prefrontal regions. rTMS could be proposed to use as an adjunctive treatment at patients having lower delta and theta cordance at frontal regions. The pretreatment QEEG appears to contain information regarding brain functioning that is relevant to, and predictive of, the therapeutic effect of the rTMS combined with SSRI antidepressant medication.

sec.title: Visual Hallucinations in Psychiatric Disorders: What Do We Currently Know?
Manisha Shenava1, Klevest Gjini1, Matcheri Keshavan1, and Nash Boutros1
sec.p: 1Department of Psychiatry, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, USA

It is generally held, though with little systematic evidence, that visual hallucinations (VH) are more characteristic of psychoses secondary to medical or neurological illness but are relatively less frequent in primary psychotic disorders. Our goal was to evaluate the current state of knowledge regarding VH in psychiatric disorders. We searched PubMed, Google Scholar, and reference lists of included articles. Search terms included VH, psychiatry, schizophrenia, and psychosis. Forty articles of VH due to neurological disorders were included in this review for comparison. We found a total of 20 Articles pertaining to VH in psychiatric disorders. Evidence shows a large range of patients with various psychiatric disorders experience VH (from 17-70% in different studies). Formed VH seem to be present more often in psychiatric disorders while unformed VH seem more likely linked to neurological conditions. Patients with childhood onset schizophrenia (COS) are also reported to have a more likely chance of having VH than their adult counterparts. Finally, some articles report a link between lower socioeconomic status or lower IQ of psychiatric patients and a higher chance of developing visual hallucinations. Contrary to standard teaching, many primary psychiatric patients have VH, in particular with a formed content. Their higher prevalence in COS and their association with low IQ may suggest a neurodevelopmental basis for these hallucinations.

sec.title: Disinhibition and Poor Error Monitoring Associated with Alcohol and Cannabis Exposure in Young Adults
Janette L. Smith1 and Richard P. Mattick1
sec.p: 1National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre, University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia

Current knowledge concerning the effects of alcohol and cannabis on cognitive function is based on older, more established/dependent users, and principally focuses on memory dysfunction alone. Our research examines a younger cohort with less exposure, but who are potentially at more risk of damage to their still-developing brains. Secondly, we combine assessment of not only memory but also executive function processes, which are increasingly important in models of the development and maintenance of substance abuse. Sixty participants aged 18-21 will undergo interviews assessing prior use of alcohol and cannabis, before completing experimental tasks assessing memory and executive functions while ERPs are recorded. Preliminary results (from ~30 participants) suggest increased alcohol use is associated with impaired inhibitory control, and impaired performance monitoring following inappropriate responses. However, memory function, attentional capture by alcohol and cannabis related words, and decision making appear unaffected by prior exposure to alcohol or cannabis. ERP data analysis is still in progress, but error-related negativity appears to be reduced in heavier drinkers. If the current results are upheld in the full sample, it suggests that a reduced ability to exert control over behavior, followed by a failure to adaptively adjust behavior after such errors, is apparent even in young adults with a shorter history of alcohol use than previously considered.

sec.title: An Analysis of Overlapping Nontarget Responses for the P300 Speller
George Townsend1 and Dean Krusienski2
sec.p: 1Algoma University, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, Canada
2Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA, USA

Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) enable devices to be controlled via thought. One BCI based on scalp EEG that detects event-related potentials (ERPs) is the popular P300 Speller. The user is presented with a matrix of flashing symbols (stimuli) and attends to the desired symbol (target) as it flashes. All other stimuli are considered nontargets. To increase the speed and accuracy of this BCI the stimuli are presented as rapidly as possible. Since there is a nontarget stimulus in every epoch, and since the responses have a time course much longer than the time between the start of each epoch, this results in overlapping epochs. We show theoretically and empirically that customary averaging of the non-target responses produces erroneous results because of this overlap. An alternative approach to nontarget response averaging is proposed that reveals the proper response. Data was collected from ten volunteers where no nontarget stimuli where flashed, then every second nontarget, then every third. For all three conditions customary averaging shows the same traditional sinusoidal ripple with a period equal to the flash period of the BCI erroneously indicating a response in every epoch. When the alternative average method is employed, the correct responses are shown in accordance with the actual non-targets flashed. The proliferation of the incorrect approach in conference papers and posters suggests that this is a widely misunderstood issue that the BCI community needs to be made aware of.

sec.title: Gamma-band Synchrony; Role of Music Perception in the Brain
Yuko Urakami1, Yoshikazu Washizawa2,3, Koki Kawamura3,4, Kazuko Hiyoshi3,5, and Andrzej Cichocki3
sec.p: 1Hospital and Research Institute, National Rehabilitation Center for Persons with Disabilities, Tokorozawa, Japan.
2Department of Communication Engineering and Informatics, The University of Electro-Communications, Tokyo, Japan.
3Laboratory for Advanced Brain Signal Processing, RIKEN Brain Science Institute, Wako-shi, Japan.
4Department of Anatomy, School of Medicine, Keio University, Tokyo, Japan.
5Department of Functional Brain Imaging, Human Brain Research Center, Graduate School of Medicine, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan.

Music perception involves acoustic and auditory scene analysis, processing of interval relations, of musical syntax and semantics, and activation of premotor representations of actions. This study aimed to clarify the neural networks during music perception of musicians and non-musicians using 60-ch electroencephalography (EEG). We collected spontaneous brain activity in five musicians (four musical-trained students and one singer), five non-musical trained students while listening to “From the new world (Dvorak)” and “Requiem (Mozart)” for three minutes, being compared with resting state. During listening to the music, compared with the resting state, gamma activity was significantly decreased, especially in the prefrontal cortex. Likewise, alpha activity was significantly decreased during listening to the music, also decreased during imaging the music as seen in the left frontal, central and parietal lobes. The rate of decrease of gamma activity in the frontal midline was greater in the anterior part (Fp1, Fp2, Fpz) compared with posterior part (F1, F2, Fz), and central part(C1, C2, Cz). During music listening, the musicians’ gamma activity was significantly decreased in the temporal, parietal and occipital lobes compared with the non musicians’. During imaging the music, the musicians’ gamma activity was significantly decreased in the temporal, parietal and occipital lobes, whereas the non musicians’ gamma activity increased in the frontal lobe. Discussion: A gamma-activity decreases during music perception especially in the anterior part of the frontal lobe; it is strongly related to the integration of recognition and emotion which reflect the processing of music in a highly integrated level. Musicians’ gamma activity significantly decreases during listening to the music in the temporal, parietal and occipital lobes compared with non musicians, which may indicate the difference of auditory-processing mechanism as concerns tones or harmony, high or low tones, forte or piano, as well as pitch and melody. The gamma synchronization shows that musicians can image the music in the same or similar condition as they are listening to the music, that is, they do image and replay the music in the recollection of acoustic memory in the listening-to-the music state. The differences in brain activities during music perception between musicians and non-musicians may reflect the different quality of their musical training experiences and expert skills.

sec.title: Pre-Attentive Auditory Evoked Potentials in Schizophrenia and Their Relationship to Psychopathology
Andrei Vedeniapin1, Cynthia L. Arfken2, Klevest Gjini2, and Nash N. Boutros2
sec.p: 1Medical University, Charleston, SC, USA
2Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, USA

Relationship among gating ratios in standard and modified gating paradigms and PANSS Scales was examined in 37 schizophrenia subjects (age: M=45.4 years). Gating parameters were also measured in 41 control subjects (age: M=39.7 years). In addition to P50, N100, and P200 potentials in gating paradigms, MMN to frequency change was measured in 17 schizophrenia subjects and 25 control subjects. Two gating paradigms (one employed two identical 1000 Hz 4mSec stimuli and the other employed two different [1000 Hz and 1500 Hz] 4mSec stimuli) and a MMN frequency deviation paradigm (the standard 1000 Hz 4mSec and the deviant 15% of time 500 Hz 4mSec stimuli) were implemented. MMN latency was significantly shorter in schizophrenia subjects. MMN latency or amplitude did not correlate with the PANSS Scales. Sensory gating was decreased in schizophrenia subjects in both sensory gating paradigms. General Psychopathology Scale was negatively correlated with N100 and P200 gating in the modified gating (MG) paradigm only. Linear regression model showed that gating ratios in the MG paradigm predicted General Psychopathology Scale (P200 ratio) and Positive and Negative Scales (P50 ratio). This is the first study that demonstrated shorter latency of frequency MMN in schizophrenia. Although schizophrenia subjects had similar gating deficit in both standard and modified gating paradigms, only gating ratios in the gating paradigm that employed non-identical stimuli were related to PANSS Scales.

sec.title: Dynamic of Spontaneous Blink Amplitude During the First rTMS Treatment Session Predicts Clinical Response in Depressed Patients
Andrei Vedeniapin1, Xingbao Li1, and Mark George1
sec.p: 1Medical University, Charleston, NC, USA

The EEG and spontaneous blink measures were studied as possible predictors of clinical response to rTMS treatment in depressed patients. The data from 7 responders and 6 non-responders participants in the OPT-TMS study (the MUSC site) were examined. Five EEG segments in the beginning and 5 EEG segments at the end of the first rTMS session were selected. Each EEG segment was about 10 sec. duration and was selected right after the end of the rTMS train. The EEG data were spectrally analyzed and traditional delta (1-3 Hz), theta (4-6 Hz), alpha (7-13 Hz) and beta (14-24 Hz) spectral bands were calculated. An amplitude of the largest blink in each EEG segment was measured and averaged across first and last five EEG segments. No difference in the spectral power dynamic during the first rTMS session was found between clinical responders and non-responders. The results, however, showed statistically significant habituation of spontaneous blink amplitude in non-responders (paired two tails t-test =3.29, p=0.022). In responders, habituation was non-significant. A ratio of the averaged blink amplitude calculated as: (last/first)*100 was larger (p=0.056)in responders. This is the first report of the high frequency rTMS effect on the blink amplitude habituation in depressed patients. There is a possible relationship of such findings to the dopaminergic system.

sec.title: The Tracing of Neural Processing on Perceptual Rivalry Using Steady-State Visual Evoked Potential
Yusuke Yokota1, Tetsuto Minami1, and Shigeki Nakauchi1
sec.p: 1Toyohashi University of Technology, Japan

Understanding of the neural processing for perceptual rivalry is one of the important topics in neurosciences. We employed bistable Necker lattice to investigate neural network during perceptual rivalry. In addition to using the Necker lattice, we focused on steady-state visual evoked potential (SSVEP) that is a powerful tool to study cognitive function. In this study, we presented flickering Necker lattice with 8 Hz and 12 Hz. It shows the different perception with different oscillatory activities. Therefore, if a participant’s perception changes from one perception to another perception, the corresponding activity changes. Our aim is to investigate the neural activities that are relevant to perceptual switching from the SSVEP. Two experiments were performed. In the one paradigm, the participants observed the flickering Necker lattice continuously and responded by pressing a button to any perceived reversal. In the other paradigm, the participants observed the flickering stable figure with one specific frequency. In this paradigm, stimulus changes from one stable figure to another stable figure with specific frequency for every specific term. We compared ambiguous reversals activity of ambiguous Necker lattice with physical reversals of stable lattice. Thirteen healthy volunteers participated in our experiments. The EEG was recorded from 64 active electrodes amplifier. Time–frequency analysis was performed by convolving the data with a complex Morlet wavelet. The differences between ambiguous and control activity were tested for statistical significance (p < 0.01) using a non-parametric permutation test (Monte Carlo randomization) repeated 1000 times. As a result, the oscillatory activity before perceptual switching showed a significant difference between ambiguous Necker lattice and stable figure at frontal region (p < 0.01). Moreover, SSVEP amplitude enhanced at occipital regions in stable figure tagging. On the other hand, it enhanced at occipito-temporal regions in ambiguous Necker tagging. These results suggested that SSVEP reflects neural different processing between ambiguous perceptual rivalry and stable physical reversal.
